title-group.article-title: Void growth and coalescence modelling in AA2050 using the Rousselier model

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Sheffield, UK
2School of Mechanical, Aerospace and Civil Engineering, The University of Manchester, UK

author-notes.corresp: M Zanganeh, Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Sheffield, Sheffield S1 3JD, UK. Email: m.zanganeh@sheffield.ac.uk

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012. Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this study, the damage evolution process in an AA2050 aluminium alloy is studied under various triaxiality levels using notched tensile specimens. The performance of the Rousselier model is assessed and it is shown that modifications are required both in the hardening curve and the damage evolution parts of the model in order to match the experimental results. The original model is corrected by adding the effect of hydrostatic pressure on the yield surface as well as implementing the Thomason coalescence model. The transferability of the Rousselier model parameters to other triaxiality levels is investigated and a procedure to identify these parameters is proposed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The assessment of high-value, safety-critical structures can, on occasions, challenge the capabilities of conventional fracture mechanics techniques. In such cases, the mechanical behaviour of the material may well be difficult to be measured in the laboratory under the same constraint conditions as experienced in the structure. Local approaches to fracture have been developed over many years as an alternative to non-linear fracture mechanics. An advantage of using local damage models is that a set of micromechanical damage parameters can be found for the material from small-scale tests which are transferable to large structures. The central assumption is that the same fracture micromechanisms govern the failure of ductile materials regardless of the size of the structure and loading conditions.

Many efforts have been made by the ductile fracture community to overcome the existing pitfalls of the conventional metal plasticity theory for ductile fracture problems using constitutive damage models. Among various studies, those of Rice and Tracey (1969), Gurson (1977), Gurson–Tvergaard–Needleman (GTN) (Gurson, 1977; Needleman, 1972; Tvergaard, 1981, 1982a, 1982b) and Rousselier (1987) have been widely referenced. GTN is probably one of the most referenced models in ductile fracture studies since it is capable of reliably predicting the predominant tensile fracture under high stress triaxiality (which is defined as σm/σeq) (Bai and Wierzbicki, 2010) or intermediate (around σmσeq=1.5) stress triaxiality levels (Pardoen and Besson, 2004) for which voids remain spherical during the growth process. Another limitation of the GTN model is its inability to capture shear fracture (Bai and Wierzbicki, 2010), although few attempts have been made to tackle this limitation (Nahshon and Hutchinson, 2008; Xue, 2008).

The Rousselier model, although based on a completely different framework, is close to the GTN model in terms of formulation (Pardoen and Besson, 2004). However, the model is not based on any particular void shape and, in contrast to the GTN model, under pure shear loading, the Rousselier model generates some damage growth, enabling it to predict the transition from a flat to a slant fracture without considering any extra nucleation and coalescence models (Lorentz et al., 2008). For these reasons, the Rousselier model was chosen in this article to study the ductile damage in AA2050 alloy.

Aluminium alloys containing lithium benefit from reduced density and increased Young’s modulus depending on the level of Li contents. AA2050 is an Al–Cu–Li alloy with medium-to-high strength and high damage tolerance and intended to out-perform the property balance of 2xxx thin plate alloys and 7xxx thick plate alloys (Lequeu et al., 2010). However, due to recent development of these materials, structural integrity studies in terms of plastic behaviour and crack growth resistance are crucial.

In this article, the damage evolution in notched tensile specimens made of AA2050 alloy is studied under various triaxiality levels. The performance of the original Rousselier model is assessed in this study and it is shown that some modifications are required both in the hardening curve and damage evolution parts of the model in order to match the experimental results.

sec.title: Rousselier model
sec.p: The Rousselier (1987) model is one of the simplest (Li et al., 1994) ductile damage models which is based on generalized continuum mechanics and thermodynamical considerations. This model describes the growth of cavities in ductile materials with the assumptions of isotropic hardening and isotropic damage.

The plastic potential, ϕ, is written as (1)ϕ=σeqr-H(α)+B(β)De(σmrΣ1) where σeq and σm are the applied equivalent stress and mean stress, respectively, Σ1 is an adjustable damage model parameter which describes the resistance of the material to the growth and coalescence of cavities and is proportional to the material flow stress (Rousselier, 1987) and D is another damage model parameter which can be deduced from experimental measurements. These parameters will be discussed in more detail in the following sections. H(α) is the hardening curve of the material, where α·=ε·=ɛ·eqp is the internal hardening and β the damage variable which is a scalar value for isotropic damage. The term β follows the rate described by equation (2) until the material softening due to void growth overtakes the material hardening. The material cannot then bear any more load and local failure happens (Shterenlikht and Howard, 2006). (2)β·growth=ε·De(σmrΣ1) where r is defined as the relative density obtained by dividing the density of the damaged material by that of the material in its initial state. In terms of damage variable and initial void volume fraction, it is stated as (3)r(β)=11-f0+f0eβ
Equation (3) is not necessarily needed to determine r. Alternatively, r can be directly calculated using the displacement field (Rousselier, 1987). Finally, B(β) is defined as (4)B(β)=Σ1f0eβ1-f0+f0eβ
B(β) can be considered as the conjugate force of the damage parameter and f=B(β)/Σ1 is representative of the current value of the void volume fraction as follows. (5)f=B(β)Σ1=f0eβ1-f0+f0eβ
It should be mentioned that the evolution of the damage parameter shown in equation (2) does not include the effect of secondary void nucleation.

sec.title: Material
sec.p:
The experimental investigation was carried out on 2050-T851 aluminium lithium alloy supplied as a 15 mm thick plate with the chemical composition presented in Table 1. Table 1.
Chemical composition of AA2050-T851 alloy.
Element Ag Zr Mn Cu Si Mg Li Zn Al
(wt %) 0.36 0.09 0.38 3.51 0.03 0.40 0.91 0.02 Balance

sec.title: Specimen geometry
sec.p: A smooth tensile specimen (G1) was used to evaluate the material properties and the hardening curve required in the Rousselier damage model. Two other notched tensile specimens (G2 and G3) with different notched radii representing different triaxiality states were employed to verify the load–diametral contraction curves predicted by the model. The use of different triaxiality levels also measures the transferability of the model to other geometries. It should be noted that all the specimens used in this study were machined from the transverse direction of the plate.

Figure 1 shows the design and dimensions of the specimens and Table 2 summarizes the specifications and triaxiality levels of each specimen. Figure 1.
Dimensions of notched tensile test specimen used in experiments (all dimensions are in mm).
Table 2.
List of specimens, important dimensions and the triaxiality levels.
Specimen Specimen type D (mm) D1 (mm) R (mm) Triaxiality (T)
G1 Smooth 10 10 ∞ 0.33
G2 Notched 10 8 6 0.57
G3 Notched 10 6 2 0.77
It is worth mentioning that the triaxiality level presented in Table 2 is an average triaxiality determined numerically on the mid cross section of the specimens.

sec.title: Experimental set-up and procedure
sec.p: A servo-hydraulic Instron 8501 test frame was used to load the specimens. All the specimens were loaded under displacement control mode with the rate of 0.01 mm/s. A standard three-dimensional (3-D) digital image correlation system (Vic3D system (Correlated Solutions)) with 5MP AVT Pike cameras was used to measure the displacement and strain fields. An extra camera was also positioned between the two DIC cameras to perform the diametral contraction measurements using digital image processor (DIP) software (Zanganeh et al., 2011) as a substitute to a clip gauge without a priori knowledge of the necking location. Further details about the experimental procedure can be found in Zanganeh et al. (2011).

sec.title: Mechanical properties
sec.p:
The longitudinal stress–strain curves were obtained from the smooth tensile specimen. The mechanical properties such as Young’s modulus, E, yield stress (0.2%), Sy, ultimate stress, Su, Poisson’s ratio, ν, and the hardening curve (equation (6)) were determined as shown in Table 3. (6)H=Kεn Table 3.
Evaluated mechanical properties for AA2050 in transverse direction.
ν E (GPa) Sy (MPa) Su (MPa) K (MPa) n
0.3 75.5 516 593 700.5 0.064

sec.title: Verification experiments
sec.p:
The diametral contraction curves obtained from the notched tensile specimens were used to assess the performance of the Rousselier model. These have been shown in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Experimental load versus diametral contraction for G1, G2 and G3 specimens.

sec.title: Modelling
sec.p:
Due to the symmetrical configuration of the specimens, one-eighth of the specimens were modelled using ABAQUS, as shown in Figure 3. To save the computational time, the elements on the mid cross section of the specimen were defined as the damage zone (the dark area in Figure 3) where the Rousselier model was applied using a VUMAT user subroutine (Shterenlikht and Howard, 2006). While in the original model both ductile and brittle failure modes were considered, the brittle part of the subroutine has been deactivated in this study. Since the subroutine is not optimized for pure ductile failure in terms of computing time, it has therefore been applied to a limited number of elements. The same approach was used previously for the modelling of grade A ship steel (Cuamatzi-Melendez, 2008) and X100 pipeline steels (Ayvar-Soberanis, 2007). Figure 3.
Finite element models used in ABAQUS.

sec.title: Evaluation of the Rousselier model parameters
sec.p: In addition to elastic material properties and the hardening curve of the material which was determined in the ‘Experiments’ section, the Rousselier model depends on the initial porosity of the material as well as two damage parameters (D and Σ1).

Although a wide range of values for D can be found in literature, it is suggested by Rousselier (Batisse et al., 1987; Rousselier et al., 1989) that D is not adjustable and is independent of the material at least for f0<10-3 and its value should be equal to 2. In contrast to D, Σ1 is more adjustable. Originally, Σ1 was found to be related to the flow curve of the material and it was suggested to be of the order of the mean value of the flow stress over the range of deformation (Rousselier, 1987). This would result in Σ1=401.7MPa for AA2050 used in this study. Although later on a mechanical testing approach was recommended to calibrate Σ1 (Rousselier et al., 1989), approximations such as Σ1=(Sy+Su)/3 are still common in literature (Tanguy and Besson, 2002). In this study, as an initial approximation, D=2 and Σ1=516+5933=369.67MPa have been used. The damage process in ductile metallic alloys usually starts by nucleation of voids around the primary particles with the size varying from 1 to 100 µm. Therefore, the initial porosity or initial void volume fraction is usually assumed to be the volume fraction of these particles. In aluminium alloys, the volume fraction of these particles range from 0.5% to 3% (Fabregue and Pardoen, 2008). Since the volume fractions of 1.1% for AA2519 (Haynes and Gangloff, 1997) and 1.15% for 6xxx (Negre et al., 2004) series are reported in literature, as a starting point, the initial volume fraction was assumed to be 1% in this study.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
The load–diametral contractions were extracted and compared (Figure 4) to the experimental results obtained using DIP as discussed in the ‘Experimental set-up and procedure’ section. Figure 4.
Comparison of experimental data (solid lines) and the Rousselier model (dashed lines).
Looking at the results, two issues are observed.

First, as it is evident from G2 and G3 specimens in Figure 4, there is a gap between the experimental curve and the Rousselier model right after the start of plastic deformation. There is no such gap for G1. The reason is simply the fact that the model was calibrated using the G1 specimen. Comparing G2 and G3 specimens, it is clear that the discrepancy between the numerical and experimental results slightly increases as the triaxiality level increases (from 0.57 in G2 to 0.77 in G3). This shows that at least for this material (AA2050), the Rousselier model is not simply transferable to other triaxiality levels unless special considerations are made. A remedy for this problem will be suggested in the following sections.

Second, although the experimental results show an abrupt fracture for all the specimens, the simulations do not predict such behaviour. This might be due to an inappropriate choice of the mesh size (which represents the microstructure). Alternatively, since the difference between the slopes of the two curves happens in the last stage of the damage process, the difference might be due to a sudden linking up and coalescence of the voids which has not been considered in the model. These will be investigated by changing the mesh size and using a coalescence model in the following sections.

sec.title: Hardening curve correction for hydrostatic pressure
sec.p: The classical metal plasticity assumes that the hydrostatic pressure has no effect on the yield surface. This basic assumption was challenged by a few researchers in 1970s including Richmond, Spitzig and Sober (Richmond and Spitzig, 1980; Spitzig et al., 1976). It was shown by Richmond that for high-strength steels, the dependency of the yield surface to the hydrostatic pressure follows the model proposed by Drucker and Prager (1952), as shown in equation (7). Such dependency has been shown for Al2024-T351 as well (Bai and Wierzbicki, 2008; Wilson, 2002). (7)σeff=σeq(ε)-aI1 where I1 is the first invariant of the stress tensor. Rewriting equation (7) in terms of triaxiality and the hardening curve yields (8)Hc=H0[1-3a(T-T0)]=cfH0 where T0 is the triaxiality corresponding to the original hardening curve (H0), T the triaxiality level for which the correction is being performed, cf a correction factor equal to 1-3a(T-T0) and a a material constant known as the Drucker–Prager constant. For Al2024, a was found to be 0.03 (Wilson, 2002). This value was used in this study as well.

Combining equations (6) and (8) gives, Kc=cfK where Kc is the corrected K. Corrected hardening curve parameters are presented in Table 4 and the corrected simulation curves are compared to the experimental results in Figure 5. Figure 5.
Comparison of the Rousselier model with corrected hardening curves (x symbols) with original model (dashed lines) and the experiments (solid lines).
Table 4.
Corrected hardening curve parameters due to hydrostatic pressure.
Specimen T T0 cf Kc (MPa) n
G2 0.57 0.33 0.983 688.59 0.064
G3 0.77 0.33 0.960 672.48 0.064

As it is observed in Figure 5, the hydrostatic pressure correction successfully corrects the previously experienced difference between the experimental curve and the Rousselier model for both triaxiality levels studied. However, the model still fails to predict the last part of the damage process.

sec.title: Effect of mesh size
sec.p:
It is very common to use load–diametral contraction curves to capture the local effects in notched tensile specimens; see Rousselier et al. (1989) and Tanguy et al. (2008) for example. It is also illustrated by Rousselier et al. (1989) that changing the mesh size can change the slope of the final stage of the load versus diametral contraction curve. For this reason, specimen G3 was meshed with three different mesh sizes (i.e. 0.2, 0.5 and 0.8 mm) to investigate the effect of mesh size on the results and specifically the slope of the last part of the curve. Results have been compared to experimental results in Figure 6. Figure 6.
Effect of mesh size on the predictions, 0.2 mm mesh size (circles), 0.5 mm mesh size (crosses) and 0.8 mm mesh size (diamonds) and comparison with experimental results (solid line).

As observed from Figure 6, the slopes of the curves are increased slightly by increasing the mesh size, especially right after the sharp drop of the load associated with the start of the coalescence process, as shown in Figure 6. However, results show that changing the mesh size does not significantly improve the overall predictions.

sec.title: Void coalescence model implementation
sec.p: As mentioned before, the Rousselier model does not account for void coalescence. There are a few models available in literature for both predicting the onset of coalescence and the coalescence process (see Benzerga and Leblond (2010) and Pardoen et al. (2010) for a detailed review). In this study, the internal necking model of Thomason (1990) was used as a criterion to predict the onset of the coalescence. After the onset of coalescence, the accelerated void growth model originally developed for the Gurson model (Tvergaard and Needleman, 1984) was adopted for the Rousselier model. Finally, these models were combined with an element removal algorithm to simulate the fracture process due to void coalescence.

The accelerated void growth model simply suggests accelerating the void growth after the onset of coalescence. Mathematically, it defines (9)f*={fiff<fcfc+δ( f-fc)otherwise where f * is the accelerated void volume fraction, δ a phenomenological multiplicative factor ranging from 3 to 8 (Pardoen and Besson, 2004) and fc the critical void volume fraction. In the case of the Gurson model, f is a direct variable in the constitutive equation. However, in the Rousselier model, f should be determined using equation (5). Knowing the values of f, δ, and fc, f* can be evaluated and converted to the Rousselier damage variable, β, using equation (10). (10)β=ln(f *1-f*1-f0f0)

It should be noted that fc can be calculated as a material-dependent constant (which is debated in literature) or alternatively a micromechanically based model such as the Thomason model can be used to calculate fc. In the latter case, fc is not a material parameter and can vary with the stress state. As mentioned before in this study, the latter approach is applied.

For a 3-D problem based on the Thomason model, coalescence starts if equation (11) is satisfied (i.e. σI/σeq reaches a critical ratio, Rc, defined by the right hand side of equation (11)). At this point fc=f (Zhang et al., 2000) (11)σIσeq=[0.1(1ϱ-1)2+1.2ϱ](1-πϱ2) where σI is the maximum principal stress and ϱ the void space ratio and is defined as (12)ϱ=23f4πeɛI+ɛII+ɛIII3/eɛII+ɛIII where ɛI, ɛII and ɛIII are the maximum, mid and minimum principal strains.

After the onset of coalescence, f in equation (12) should be replaced by f *. With the evolution of the damage process, the critical ratio decreases. The element is removed when the critical ratio reaches zero (which means the element has no more load-carrying capacity). The whole procedure has been summarized in Figure 7. Figure 7.
Flowchart showing the procedure used to implement the coalescence model and element removal.

sec.title: Results of void coalescence implementation
sec.p:
As shown in Figure 8, the addition of the Thomason coalescence model along with an element removal algorithm predicts the sudden failure of the material. However, the fracture points, although much better predicted than with the original Rousselier model, are still slightly off from the experimental results. Σ1 is one of the parameters that influences the prediction of the fracture point. As mentioned earlier, the damage parameters included in the Rousselier model are not representative of any physical quantity. The value of 369.67 MPa used here for Σ1 is based on an approximate formula recommended in literature. Σ1=401.7MPa could also be used from the definition of Σ1 presented by Rousselier. The simulations were repeated using Σ1=401.7MPa and the results are presented in Figure 9. Figure 8.
Comparison between the experimental results (solid lines), the original Rousselier model (dots) and the modified model (dashed lines).
Figure 9.
Comparison between experiments (solid lines) and results of the modified model Σ1=369.67MPa (dashed lines) and Σ1=401.70MPa (dots).

According to Figure 9, the value of Σ1 = 401.70 MPa has improved the results especially for specimen G3. However, the results for specimen G2, although improved, still show some differences compared to the experimental results. Although using a higher value of Σ1 results in a better fit for the G3 case (best fit was achieved using Σ1 = 460 MPa, as shown in Figure 10), a different value of Σ1 is required for the G2 specimens (best fit for G2 was achieved using Σ1 = 475 MPa, as shown in Figure 10). In other words, Σ1 is not very transferable between various triaxiality levels. An alternative way of identifying the damage parameters is therefore required to generate reliable fracture point predictions for different triaxiality levels. Figure 10.
Comparison between experimental results (solid lines) and simulations (dashed lines) using D=2 and Σ1=460MPa for G3 and D=2 and Σ1=475MPa for G2 specimens.

To investigate whether other combinations of DandΣ1 could result in similar predictions or not, two other values for D (i.e. D=0.28 and D=1.55) were selected, and the corresponding values of Σ1 were determined for both G2 and G3 specimens, as given in Table 5. Table 5.
Combinations of D and Σ1 which result in good matches between the model and the experiments.
Specimen T D Σ1([MPa)] ΔΣ1/ΔT
G2 0.57 0.28 154 165
G3 0.77 0.28 187
G2 0.57 1.55 375 55
G3 0.77 1.55 386
G2 0.57 2 476 −80
G3 0.77 2 460

As shown in Figure 11, for D=0.28, for example, simulation results perfectly fit the experimental results but with a different value for Σ1 compared to the case D = 2. Other combinations of D and Σ1 (as presented in Table 5) can give similar results. Table 5 shows that for smaller values of D, the required Σ1 is higher for higher triaxiality levels. However, for higher values of D (e.g. D=2) the required Σ1 is slightly higher for lower triaxiality levels. In other words, Σ1 variation due to changing the triaxiality level, i.e. ΔΣ1/ΔT, is decreasing as D increases. Based on Table 5, ΔΣ1/ΔT is positive for D=0.28andD=1.55 while it is negative for D=2. This suggests that a value for D (between 1.55 and 2) can be found such that ΔΣ1/ΔT=0. Finding such a value for D would solve the transferability issue of the Rousselier model at least for the range of triaxiality levels studied and would help establish a procedure for the calibration of the Rousselier model parameters. Figure 11.
Comparison between experimental results (solid lines) and simulations (dashed lines) using D=0.28andΣ1=187MPa for G3 and D=0.28andΣ1=154MPa for G2 specimens.

A graphical approach to find D with constant values of Σ1 is to fit a surface to the data points available in the T, D and Σ1 space (similar to those data presented in Table 5) and to look at the projection of the surface on the T–D plane, as shown in Figure 12. This results in a contour map from which an approximation for D and Σ1 can be found. Figure 12.
Map of the variation of D with T for constant Σ1values.

Figure 12 shows that for Σ1 = 420 MPa, D is almost constant and equal to about 1.78 for the range of triaxiality shown in Figure 12. These values were applied in the simulations and the corresponding load versus diametral contraction is shown in Figure 13. Figure 13.
Comparison between experimental results (solid lines) and the modified Rousselier model using D=1.78andΣ1=420MPa obtained from Figure 12.

Based on the above discussion, the following procedure is suggested for the identification of the Rousselier model parameters (i.e. D and Σ1) using load versus diametral contraction curves.
At least two specimens with different triaxiality levels are required (the more the better).
For each specimen (with a corresponding triaxiality level), the model should be fitted to the experimental results using different values of D andΣ1. Each set of T, D andΣ1 would represent a data point. The higher the number of data points the more accurate the identified parameters (in this study three data points were used for each triaxiality level).
The values of D used in the previous step should be used to model other triaxiality levels and Σ1 should be adjusted by fitting the predicted curves to the experimental results.
A surface should be fitted to the data points obtained in steps 2 and 3.
The projection of the surface obtained in step 4 on the T–D plane reveals a contour showing the variation of D with T for constant Σ1 values.
The value of D corresponding to a constant Σ1 over the range of triaxiality and Σ1 itself are therefore the identified parameters of the Rousselier model.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
The damage evolution in notched tensile specimens made of AA2050 alloy was studied under various triaxiality levels and the performance of the Rousselier model was assessed using load versus diametral contraction curves. Based on the results found, the following conclusions can be made.
The original Rousselier model over-estimates the behaviour of the studied material both in the plastic flow and damage evolution parts of the tensile curve and more specifically in the final part of the damage process. The difference between the model and experimental results increases with an increase in the triaxiality level.
The introduction of the effect of hydrostatic pressure in the constitutive equations of the material successfully corrected the predictions given by the Rousselier model as far as the plastic flow part of the tensile curve is concerned.
It was shown that the Rousselier model does not match well the experimental results for the final fracture process. This was corrected by adding a physically based coalescence model (Thomason model) and using an element removal approach.
The suggested tuning procedures described in literature for the calibration of the Rousselier model parameters were found to be not very accurate and not transferable to other triaxiality levels.
It was shown that at least for this material, the experimental data corresponding to a single triaxiality level is not sufficient for the identification of the Rousselier model parameters.
For the investigated material, it was found that the Rousselier parameters are not unique and that several combinations of the two model parameters can give similar results which makes the transferability of the model to other triaxiality level questionable. A procedure was also proposed to resolve this problem.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The authors gratefully acknowledge the financial support provided by EPSRC for this study through grant EP/F023464/1.

ack.p: They also thank Dr Yee Han Tai for his contribution in performing the experiments.
